Internationale Kooperation in sozialpädagogischer Ausbildung und Praxis
Galmpton C of E Primary School

According to changes in society due to immigration, work related migration and the attractiveness of Germany as an international hotspot of innovation and science the project responds to the increased national need of experienced childcare practitioners and special needs practitioners with intercultural competence.
Complementing the experience of prior projetcs the current project application adds decisive aspects, which demand a deepened contrastive view of own and foreign culture as well as own and foreign understanding of education: the work placement abroad is preceded by an intensive work related and language related preparation in a mandatory course "Intercultural Education" comprising 360 hours. Part of that will be a cooperation in international teams with students of South Devon College on certain topics. Learning results and products will be documented using electronic media like online platforms as MAHARA. During the mobility results of the international work teams will be presented. Hence the preparation of the beneficiaries will follow the CLIL method (content and language integrated learning). Values as understanding, acceptance of diversity, tolerance which are conveyed within that project stage will help the beneficiaries putting the current concept of inclusion into place in Germany.

The intended 40 mobilities will be split into two mobility flows of 20 participants each that will last for four weeks. Those will take place in spring 2015 and 2016 accompanied by experienced teaching staff.
  
During the mobility apprentices in childcare and education in their second year of training will get to know a well established system of full day schooling at British primary schools which is supported by educational support staff. The observation and support of that group of professionals by the participants is seen with regard to the current change of German schools towards inclusive whole day care provision and the increased need of professionalised educational support staff in that field. The beneficiaries will investigate tools of scheduling day structure, differentiation and inclusion as well as strategies of cooperation between professions at school. A short induction course at South Devon College carried out by British students and their teachers will provide the theoretical basis and will result in an additional certificate of participation. Acquired methods of good practice will be applied in an educational activity planned and carried out by participants. The project responds to claims of politics and research for trained childcare practitioners who are trained especially in the field of full day schooling and the pressure for innovation within that new field of work. 

In accordance with the lately introduced personal budget for people with special needs in Germany future special needs practitioners investigate their forthcoming revised role looking for ways to continue to develop in their role. On placement in various British organisations of special needs care and education they will test the successfully applied concept of Person Centred Planning (PCP) in how far the degree of self-determination of clients can be increased and which measures have to be concluded for their work in Germany.

Young people in initial vocational training will develop professional identity in fields of work which are determined by significant changes and increased demands. They will take part in innovation and will increase their prospects on the job market. They will acquire necessary competences to work at bilingual organisations or with people who have migrated to Germany or to foster participation of people with special needs in settings of inclusion.

This proposal “Erdi Heziketa 2016” is aimed at 22 young students, of Initial Vocational Training of 30 professional training center located in the Basque Country. Also for personal or staff of the training centres to develop a training period on job-shadowing.

This new proposal includes the following partners:

-Confebask as proposal's oordinator.
-Vocational training schools included on the consortium, both public and private, belonging to the Training Network of Centres of the Basque Country, as sending institutions.
- The Department of Education of the Basque Government, Provincial Councils as Institutional and co-financiers partners.
- Intermediary partners and Host organizations in Italy, Portugal and the UK.

The objectives and expected results are the achievement of meeting the following needs of the participants covered by this proposal: 
- Improvement of practical training, in addition to theoretical training gained during their training period in their centers. Provide participants with practical training through the 3 months-stay in businesses in Italy, Portugal or the UK, thus enabling the Technician qualification through recognition of the stay by the form of Training at Work or FCT. These stays will be developed between March and June 2017. 
- Improvement of their language skills: Learning and/or improvement of one or more languages (Italian / Portuguese / English): general knowledge and technical information relating to their professional field.
- Improvement of Professional Skills: Participants acquire skills and abilities terminals set in the training program placement module, which enable them to carry out their profession. Development of a set of capabilities or skills necessary for incorporation into the workforce.
- Improvement of Cultural and Personal Skills: It is, in many cases, the first experience and stay abroad, which implies personal maturity. To live in a multicultural environment, involves the acquisition of a spirit of adaptation to different social-cultural as well as a huge cultural enrichment. 
- Promote and encourage VET innovation and internationalization through personal placements job-shadowing).

Confebask has been participating for over 15 years in European mobility projects, with a baggage accumulated over 1600 participants so that vocational students are concerned. It uses a process management through a methodology of continuous improvement (PDCA) managed directly by Confebask, and applied to all our projects.
The Website  "Professional Training Erasmus+ Grants” is established, as the fundamental axis in the management, being the main channel of communication between partners. Through this website, the training centers send to Confebask their students-candidates. It is performed the selection of participants, and especially, becomes the key to monitoring and mentoring of the stages, once started stays abroad. Also, this tool is essential for economic management of the project itself led by the coordinator.
Confebask as project coordinator, will support in its initial phase (October 2016 - February 2017) including supporting sending partners and their tutors, selecting participants and identifying skills to be developed in host companies.
During the stay in the country of destination (March-June 2017) you will be monitored and supported by an intermediary partner/ host organisation,  who will manage the participants’ accommodation and arrvial support, and who will perform direct follow-up work through a methodology defined by Confebask as “Learning to Learn”.  In the final phase (July - October 2017) you will proceed to the global evaluation of the project and the participants carried out by the instructor (host partner) and tutor (Professional Training sending centre).

CONTEXT
We want to foster our students’ competence on their second languages, as they have few chances to practice them in real contexts.  The improvement of their transversal competences will be crucial as well: using ICT tools to search and present information, developing entrepeneurship to develop activities with a real and useful purpose, reflecting on their own learning process, etc. 
Teachers also needs new experiences, methodologies and techniques to teach languages.  They will prepare didactic sequences and tasks related to sociocultural aspects and intercultural awareness, sharing them during the transnational meetings and on the Internet to later use them with the students.

OBJECTIVES AND TOPICS
1- Get to know and value the sociocultural diversity showing attitudes of respect and tolerance.
2- Improve linguistic competence of second languages in real contexts.
3- Use ITC tools autonomously to search for information, analyze it and present it.
4- Transfer, learn and apply quality teaching methods.
5- Foster dialogue and individual or group decision taking.
6- Foster artistic creativity.
We will focus on the preparation and implementation of integrated tasks taking the following topics into account:
a- Culture and creativity: the nucleus of the activities will have to do with the cultural knowledge of the countries involved (festivals, music, gastronomy, art, sport, etc.).
b- Second language teaching and learning: students/teachers will use the languages they learn/teach: Spanish, English, Italian and some German.
c- ICT – New technologies – Digital competence.

PARTICIPANTS
Most of our 12-17 year-old students find few opportunities to practise the language they learn in their environment (three out of four schools are in small towns, and two of them suffer the difficult economic crisis in Spain and Italy), with little or no contact with native speakers. than 200 participants will benefit from this Project, indirectly more than 2000.
Teachers want to increase their abilities in the second language classroom, learning new pedagogical approaches, preparing integrated activities that may favour its implementation among their students and looking for better methods to evaluate them.

ACTIVITIES
- Website to publish our activities and results.
- Twinspace to communicate among students, create a logo, a song, a calendar, etc.
- Travel guide, which will be used by students in their mobility activities.
- Integrated didactic sequences (two per partner) and others about music, sport, art and gastronomy.
- Rubric system to evaluate the project.
- Article about second language teaching by comparison of methods.
- Multilingual dictionary with useful expressions.
- Boardgame about sociocultural aspects.
- Benefic calendar on festivities and traditions.
- Mobility activities: shadow teaching (Spanish teachers in the UK, Austrian teachers in Spain, Italian teachers in Austria and English teachers in Spain) plus students’ activities (art in Austria, sports in Italy, music in Spain and gastronomy in the United Kingdom). There will also be immersion actviities to participate in integrated tasks or to participate in normal classes.

METHODOLOGY
We will present integrated tasks related to sociocultural aspects and different subjects of the curriculum. We will deal with project-based learning, problem-based learning, gamification, blended learning, etc. These tasks will have a communicative approach and will be developed in cooperative or colaborative groups.  The situations will make our students take decision, develop entrepeneurship and ICT use. Teachers will learn new teaching methods, share activities, experiences, resources, etc. They will also take part in shadow-teaching activities to observe and participate in the partners’ schools, in which they will prpare didactic sequences taking their students' necessities into account. We have prepared four transnational meetings.

RESULTS AND IMPACT
- Students: knowledge on their own culture and others’; transversal and linguistic competence improvement; better school-results, etc.
- Families: harmony days, meetings, students’ accommodation, etc.
- Teachers: new educational systems, values and pedagogical approaches, improvement of their linguistic competences.
- Schools: new European bonds, development of resources and materials, etc.
- Town and region: promotion of the places, European identity, etc.

LONG-TERM BENEFITS
The didactic sequences or tasks will be used in future academic years. Its dissemination will allow other teachers to use them in their context. Friendship and teaching bonds for future projects.

"Could the lights go off across Europe?  Cooperation to shape an all renewable vision 
for Europe by 2050."

"Could the lights go off across Europe?  Cooperation to shape an all renewable vision for Europe by 2050." 
 
Inspired by the hardrainproject’s web of energy (www.hardrainproject.com/web_of_energy ) this project will explore how our 
activities and attitudes will have to be altered if we want to change from carbon energy - coal, oil and gas - to renewable energies: solar, wind, hydro, wave and geothermal energy generation.   
The 2050 vision requires simultaneous and coordinated progress on many levels as well as a cooperation between governments, 
industry and consumers. Are we ready to seize the day and collaborate on a solution which is European-wide? 
Following new guidelines on the optimization of transnational energy flows which were published in April 2014, our project aims at 
building and strengthening cooperation among schools from different European countries. We hereby want to offer adolescents 
from different regions a profound, long-lasting and consequently European perspective on two topics which will shape many 
generations to come: sustainability and renewable energies. The central aim of the project is to offer students and teachers a first-
hand encounter with different technologies that use renewable energies. Different countries offer different ways of implementing 
renewable energies. Getting to know these various ways of using renewable energies on-site will broaden our students' horizons 
and thus lead to a sustainable and long-lasting learning effect. They will learn in which ways their everyday behaviour has an effect on the global environment by actively learning about the connectedness of different European regions and their respective use of 
renewable energies. Thus they will learn not regard themselves as isolated individuals from a certain region, but as active and 
effective European agents for change. They will improve their language skills through different communication forms (face-to-face 
communication, email, eTwinning, homepages, skype, facebook, google docs etc.) methodical skills (preparing presentations, 
conducting workshops, designing leaflets etc.) and gain a deeper understanding of the shared European heritage and responsibility. 
Owing to the past Comenius project in which the partners from Germany, England and Norway took part, there is a common 
ground from which the new project can be launched. The addition of Portugal as a fourth partner will enrich our project and lead 
to even more comprehensive discussions and results. Since all schools are situated in UNESCO Geoparks in rural areas and are 
specialized in Geography and Science, we can all benefit from the different national ways of approaching the topics of sustainability and renewable energies. Due to already established external partnerships such as affiliations with regional companies (e.g. ENO, Steiff in Buchen) or research institutions (e.g. South West Energy Centre, Paignton, Aveiro University Campus) we can conduct highly 
efficient exchange trips for five students and two teachers to the different countries where we are planning to hold lectures, take part in workshops, conduct student presentations, attend discussions etc.   
The possible stages of the project (raising awareness within & between our communities, challenges we are facing now and in the 
future, responses: from local to national solutions, a web of energy - a 2050 all renewable European supergrid?) could serve as 
multiplication activities for the teaching staff (internal training programs, school conferences on relevant topics etc.) as well as for 
students (the projects topics will be presented in different subjects). Besides using our findings in school contexts, we are 
planning to publish our results through different media, on our homepages and in permanent exhibitions in our school buildings as well as in communal buildings. This will offer the chance to continuously evaluate our procedures and share our thoughts with the other partners based on feedback sessions. Additionally, we are not only planning to build models of photovoltaic systems, but also to shoot video clips about the individual school projects which will be combined to comprise a longer film about our conjoined 
project.  
The students will thus acquire expert knowledge about renewable energies, improve their language skills as well as gain access to universities and other external partners such as companies or political boards and parties. Most importantly, they will actively participate in formulating and realizing the European vision of sustainability and energy efficiency. They will act as active multipliers for the project's central aim by not only learning about renewable energies, but also integrating them into their daily life and thus influencing their social environment. The project's scope reaches far beyond the walls of our schools and will contribute to a coordinated European step towards sustainability and renewable energies.
